Entity-patch.label: patches
Entity-patch.description: In the context of software development, 'patches' refer to updates or modifications made to the codebase that enhance functionality, fix bugs, or improve performance, particularly in open-source projects like those related to the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-2016.description: The mention '2016' refers to the year when the Debian project, which had produced a port for RISC-V, was closed due to copyright reasons.

Entity-glibc.label: Glibc
Entity-glibc.description: Glibc is a widely used implementation of the standard C library for the GNU operating system, providing essential functions for C programming.

Entity-64-bit_only_architecture.label: 64-bit only architecture
Entity-64-bit_only_architecture.description: A 64-bit only architecture refers to a computer architecture that exclusively supports 64-bit data processing and operations, without compatibility for 32-bit instructions or applications.

Entity-computing_environment.label: computing environment
Entity-computing_environment.description: A computing environment refers to the combination of hardware and software resources that provide the necessary infrastructure for executing computational tasks and applications.

Entity-linux_from_scratch.label: Linux from Scratch
Entity-linux_from_scratch.description: Linux from Scratch is a project that provides a step-by-step guide for building a custom Linux operating system from the ground up, allowing users to understand the inner workings of Linux and tailor it to their specific needs.

Entity-physical_hardware.label: physical hardware
Entity-physical_hardware.description: Physical hardware refers to the tangible components of a computer system, including devices such as processors, memory, storage, and peripherals, that are essential for its operation.

Entity-sponsor.label: sponsors
Entity-sponsor.description: The term 'sponsors' refers to the organizations or entities that provide financial support and funding for research and development studies related to RISC-V processors.

Entity-hardware.label: hardware
Entity-hardware.description: Hardware refers to the physical components and devices that make up a computer system, enabling it to function and run software applications.

Entity-linux_from_scratch_directive.label: Linux from Scratch directives
Entity-linux_from_scratch_directive.description: Linux from Scratch directives are a set of guidelines and instructions used to build a custom Linux operating system from the ground up, allowing users to configure and compile their own Linux system tailored to specific needs.

Entity-processor_design.label: processor design
Entity-processor_design.description: Processor design refers to the engineering process and methodologies involved in creating the architecture, functionality, and implementation of a computer processor.

Entity-linux_kernel_3.1.label: Linux kernel 3.1
Entity-linux_kernel_3.1.description: Linux kernel 3.1 is a version of the Linux kernel, which is the core component of the Linux operating system responsible for managing hardware and system resources.

Entity-kernel_and_user_space_software.label: kernel and user space software
Entity-kernel_and_user_space_software.description: Kernel and user space software refers to the components of an operating system where the kernel operates in a privileged mode managing hardware resources, while user space software runs in a restricted mode, providing applications and services that interact with the kernel.

Entity-debian.label: Debian
Entity-debian.description: Debian is a widely used open-source operating system based on the Linux kernel, known for its stability and extensive software repository.

Entity-independent_base.label: independent base
Entity-independent_base.description: The term 'independent base' refers to the unique foundational structure of the MILIS Linux operating system, which is not derived from any existing Linux distribution and features its own package management system.

Entity-llvm_compiler_infrastructure.label: LLVM Compiler Infrastructure
Entity-llvm_compiler_infrastructure.description: LLVM Compiler Infrastructure is a collection of modular and reusable compiler and toolchain technologies that enable the development of compiler frameworks and support various programming languages.

Entity-organizational_use.label: organizational use
Entity-organizational_use.description: The term 'organizational use' refers to the intended application of the MILIS Linux operating system, which aims to provide a free and user-friendly platform specifically designed for use by organizations, in addition to individual users.

Entity-individual_and_organizational_use.label: individual and organizational use
Entity-individual_and_organizational_use.description: The term 'individual and organizational use' refers to the intended application of the MILIS Linux operating system, which aims to provide a user-friendly and accessible platform for both private users and commercial entities.

Entity-register_area.label: register areas
Entity-register_area.description: Register areas refer to designated sections of a processor's memory that are used to store temporary data and instructions, allowing for efficient memory management and faster execution of programs in computer architecture.

Entity-processor_capability.label: processor capabilities
Entity-processor_capability.description: Processor capabilities refer to the features and performance attributes of a processor that determine its ability to execute instructions and handle tasks efficiently.

Entity-target_user_of_milis.label: Target users of MILIS
Entity-target_user_of_milis.description: The target users of MILIS are primarily government agencies, commercial organizations, and private users who seek a free and easy-to-use operating system.

Entity-package_production_collection.label: package production collection
Entity-package_production_collection.description: The 'package production collection' refers to a proprietary set of software packages developed specifically for the MILIS Linux operating system, enabling it to manage and install software independently from other Linux distributions.

Entity-64-bit.label: 64-bit
Entity-64-bit.description: 64-bit refers to a data type or computer architecture that uses 64 bits to represent data, allowing for a larger range of values and improved performance in processing compared to lower bit architectures.

Entity-userspace.label: userspace
Entity-userspace.description: Userspace refers to the memory space in an operating system where user applications run, distinct from the kernel space where the core of the operating system operates.

Entity-closed_and_license_problem.label: closed and license problems
Entity-closed_and_license_problem.description: The term 'closed and license problems' refers to the limitations and restrictions imposed by proprietary licensing agreements and the lack of openness in hardware designs that hinder innovation and development in the processor market.

Entity-uclibc.label: Uclibc
Entity-uclibc.description: Uclibc is a lightweight C standard library designed for embedded systems and resource-constrained environments.

Entity-runtime_condition.label: runtime conditions
aliases: the runtime conditions of the system
Entity-runtime_condition.description: The term 'runtime conditions' refers to the operational states and parameters of a computing system that can affect its performance and security, particularly those that are not readily observable, such as those associated with the Intel management engine.

mentions.local_name: the runtime conditions of the system

Entity-chip_production.label: chip production
Entity-chip_production.description: Chip production refers to the process of manufacturing semiconductor chips, which are essential components in electronic devices and systems.

Entity-open_source_synergy.label: open source synergy
Entity-open_source_synergy.description: Open source synergy refers to the collaborative benefits and innovations that arise from the integration of open source software, like the Linux kernel, with hardware development, particularly in enhancing security and functionality in computing systems.

Entity-open_source_hardware_initiative.label: open source hardware initiative
Entity-open_source_hardware_initiative.description: The open source hardware initiative is a collaborative project aimed at promoting the development and sharing of hardware designs and technologies in an open and accessible manner.

Entity-extension_to_basic_isa.label: extensions to basic ISA
Entity-extension_to_basic_isa.description: Extensions to basic ISA refer to the additional functionalities or specialized instructions that can be integrated into the fundamental Instruction Set Architecture (ISA) to enhance its capabilities for specific applications or configurations.

Entity-gnulinux_project.label: GNU/Linux projects
Entity-gnulinux_project.description: GNU/Linux projects refer to various open-source operating system initiatives based on the GNU and Linux software components, which include distinct distributions like MILIS Linux that are developed independently and often feature unique package management systems.

Entity-root_file_system.label: root file system
Entity-root_file_system.description: The root file system is the top-level directory in a file system hierarchy, containing all other directories and files, and is essential for the operation of an operating system.

Entity-open_source_operating_system_deve.label: open source operating system development project
aliases: open source operating system development project
Entity-open_source_operating_system_deve.description: An open source operating system development project is a collaborative initiative aimed at creating, improving, and distributing an operating system that is freely available for use, modification, and distribution by anyone.

mentions.local_name: open source operating system development project

Entity-musl.label: Musl
Entity-musl.description: Musl is a lightweight and efficient implementation of the standard C library designed for Linux-based systems.

Entity-secure_network_structure.label: Secure network structure
Entity-secure_network_structure.description: The 'Secure network structure' refers to a configurable framework within the MILIS Linux project that allows users to establish a secure network environment through a web browser interface.

Entity-linux_image.label: Linux images
Entity-linux_image.description: Linux images refer to packaged versions of the Linux operating system that can be deployed on various hardware platforms, often including the kernel and necessary software components for system operation.

Entity-system_emulation.label: System Emulation
Entity-system_emulation.description: System Emulation is a computing technique that allows one system to mimic the functions and operations of another system, enabling software and applications designed for the emulated system to run on a different hardware or software environment.

Entity-development_community.label: development community
Entity-development_community.description: The development community refers to a collective group of individuals and organizations actively engaged in the collaborative development and enhancement of open-source projects, particularly in the context of RISC-V architecture, facilitating the sharing of ideas and contributions.

Entity-hardware_level.label: hardware level
Entity-hardware_level.description: The term 'hardware level' refers to the foundational layer of a computing system that encompasses the physical components and architecture, which can influence the overall security and performance of the system.

Entity-gnulinux.label: GNU/Linux
Entity-gnulinux.description: GNU/Linux is a free and open-source operating system that combines the GNU software system with the Linux kernel, commonly used as a platform for various software applications and distributions.

Entity-toolchain.label: Toolchain
Entity-toolchain.description: A toolchain is a set of programming tools that are used together to produce a software application, typically including a compiler, linker, and libraries.

Entity-compiler_implementation.label: compiler implementations
Entity-compiler_implementation.description: Compiler implementations refer to the various software systems and tools that translate high-level programming languages into machine code or intermediate code, enabling the execution of programs on computer hardware.

Entity-new_generation_processor.label: new generation processors
Entity-new_generation_processor.description: New generation processors are advanced computing units designed to enhance performance and efficiency, often incorporating modern architectures and technologies.

Entity-user-space_application_level.label: user-space application level
Entity-user-space_application_level.description: The user-space application level refers to the environment in an operating system where applications run outside of the kernel, allowing them to operate with user privileges and access system resources without direct interaction with the core system functions.

Entity-open_source_ecosystem.label: open source ecosystem
Entity-open_source_ecosystem.description: The open source ecosystem refers to a collaborative environment where software, hardware, and other resources are developed and shared openly, allowing for community participation, innovation, and the free exchange of ideas and technologies.

Entity-meltdown.label: Meltdown
Entity-meltdown.description: Meltdown refers to a significant security vulnerability that affects modern microprocessors, allowing unauthorized access to sensitive data by exploiting the speculative execution feature of CPUs.

Entity-linux_tree.label: Linux tree
Entity-linux_tree.description: The Linux tree refers to the main repository of the Linux operating system's source code, which is used for software development and version control of its various components and features.

Entity-security.label: security
Entity-security.description: In the context of this paper, 'security' refers to the measures and practices necessary to protect computing systems from vulnerabilities, particularly emphasizing the importance of hardware-level security to mitigate risks such as those exposed by the Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities.

Entity-binutils_2.30.label: Binutils 2.30
Entity-binutils_2.30.description: Binutils 2.30 is a version of the GNU Binary Utilities, a collection of tools used for handling binary files, which is required for building kernels in RISC-V architecture when used in conjunction with GCC version 7.1 or higher.

Entity-vulnerability.label: vulnerability
Entity-vulnerability.description: The mention 'vulnerability' refers to security weaknesses in computing systems, specifically highlighting the need for addressing hardware-level flaws, such as those exposed by the Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities, to ensure overall system security.

Entity-high_security_at_software_level.label: high security at software level
Entity-high_security_at_software_level.description: High security at software level refers to the implementation of robust security measures and protocols within software systems to protect against vulnerabilities and attacks, although it is noted that such measures may still be insufficient without corresponding security at the hardware level.

Entity-embedded_device.label: embedded devices
Entity-embedded_device.description: Embedded devices are specialized computing systems designed to perform dedicated functions within larger systems, often characterized by their integration into hardware and limited user interfaces.

Entity-target_file_system.label: target file system
Entity-target_file_system.description: The target file system refers to a specific file system environment or structure that is intended to receive and run software packages compiled for a particular architecture or platform.

Entity-kernel_porting.label: kernel porting
Entity-kernel_porting.description: Kernel porting is the process of adapting a computer operating system kernel to run on a different hardware architecture or platform.

Entity-open_development_platform.label: open development platform
Entity-open_development_platform.description: The 'open development platform' refers to a collaborative environment within the MILIS Linux project that enables developers to utilize and enhance a pure Linux experience, facilitating independent software development and innovation.

Entity-license_term_limitation.label: license term limitations
Entity-license_term_limitation.description: License term limitations refer to the restrictions imposed on the production and distribution of ARM processors, which affect their design and usage due to licensing agreements.

Entity-technique.label: techniques
Entity-technique.description: In the context of the MILIS Linux project, 'techniques' refers to the methods and practices employed in the implementation of the Linux distribution, specifically those derived from the Linux from Scratch (LFS) approach.

Entity-computer.label: computer
Entity-computer.description: A computer is an electronic device that processes data and performs calculations according to a set of instructions, enabling various applications and tasks.

Entity-port_migration.label: port migration
aliases: port migration of different Linux distributions
Entity-port_migration.description: Port migration refers to the process of adapting and transferring different Linux distributions to operate on a new architecture, specifically in the context of developing an open source and reliable user ecosystem on the Linux kernel.

mentions.local_name: port migration of different Linux distributions

Entity-this_vulnerability.label: this vulnerability
Entity-this_vulnerability.description: This vulnerability refers to the security weaknesses in computing systems that arise from hardware-level issues, specifically highlighted by the Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities, which necessitate the use of open source solutions in the Linux kernel to enhance security.

Entity-qemu.label: QEMU
Entity-qemu.description: QEMU is an open-source emulator and virtual machine tool that allows users to run operating systems and applications for different architectures on a host system.

Entity-it_process.label: IT process
Entity-it_process.description: An IT process refers to a structured set of activities or tasks that are designed to manage and deliver information technology services and solutions effectively.

Entity-great_improvement.label: great improvements
Entity-great_improvement.description: The term 'great improvements' refers to significant advancements in the processor market that have been hindered by issues related to closed architectures and licensing restrictions.

Entity-lf.label: LFS
Entity-lf.description: LFS refers to 'Linux from Scratch', a technique used to build a custom Linux distribution from the ground up, allowing users to create a tailored operating system by compiling and configuring all components manually.

Entity-rootfs.label: Rootfs
Entity-rootfs.description: Rootfs is a type of filesystem used in operating systems, particularly in Linux, that serves as the root filesystem containing the essential files and directories needed for the system to boot and operate.

Entity-live_image.label: live image
Entity-live_image.description: A live image refers to a bootable operating system environment that can run directly from a virtual board, allowing users to interact with the system without installation on physical hardware.

Entity-reference_implementation.label: reference implementation
Entity-reference_implementation.description: A reference implementation is a standard or prototype version of a software system that serves as a benchmark for developers to understand the functionality and design of the system.

Entity-processor_manufacturer.label: processor manufacturers
Entity-processor_manufacturer.description: Processor manufacturers are companies or organizations that design and produce microprocessors and related semiconductor devices used in various computing systems.

Entity-userspace_package.label: userspace packages
Entity-userspace_package.description: Userspace packages are software components designed to run in the user space of an operating system, providing applications and services that operate independently of the kernel.

Entity-base_file_system.label: base file system
Entity-base_file_system.description: The base file system refers to the foundational structure of a file system that provides essential components and services for managing files and directories in a computing environment.

Entity-open_source_software_ecosystem.label: open source software ecosystem
Entity-open_source_software_ecosystem.description: An open source software ecosystem is a collaborative environment where software is developed, shared, and maintained under open source licenses, allowing users to freely access, modify, and distribute the software.

Entity-linux_kit.label: Linux Kit
Entity-linux_kit.description: Linux Kit is a tool for building and customizing minimal Linux distributions, often used for creating lightweight container environments.

Entity-128-bit_operation.label: 128-bit operation
Entity-128-bit_operation.description: A 128-bit operation refers to a computational process that handles data in 128-bit chunks, typically used in cryptography and high-performance computing.

Entity-processing_power.label: processing power
Entity-processing_power.description: Processing power refers to the capacity of a computer or computing device to execute instructions and perform calculations, typically measured in terms of speed and efficiency.

Entity-user_space_software.label: user space software
Entity-user_space_software.description: User space software refers to applications and components that run in the user space of an operating system, as opposed to the kernel space, allowing for user-level processes and interactions.

Entity-buildroot.label: Buildroot
Entity-buildroot.description: Buildroot is a build system that simplifies the process of creating custom Linux distributions for embedded systems.

Entity-memory_management.label: memory management
Entity-memory_management.description: Memory management refers to the process of coordinating and handling computer memory resources, including the allocation, use, and release of memory during program execution to optimize performance and ensure efficient operation.

Entity-open_source.label: open source
Entity-open_source.description: Open source refers to a software development and licensing model that allows users to freely access, modify, and distribute the source code of software, promoting collaborative development and transparency.

Entity-c_library.label: C libraries
Entity-c_library.description: C libraries are collections of pre-written code in the C programming language that provide reusable functions and routines for software development.

Entity-weakness_of_computing.label: weakness of computing
Entity-weakness_of_computing.description: The term 'weakness of computing' refers to vulnerabilities in computing systems, particularly those that arise from hardware-level issues, as exemplified by the Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities, which persist despite high security measures at the software level.

Entity-silver_member.label: silver member
Entity-silver_member.description: The term 'silver member' refers to ASELSAN's membership status within the RISC-V foundation, indicating a level of participation and support for the development of the RISC-V architecture.

Entity-paging_and_mmu.label: Paging and MMU
Entity-paging_and_mmu.description: Paging and MMU refer to the mechanisms and hardware components used in computer systems for managing memory, where paging is a memory management scheme that eliminates the need for contiguous allocation of physical memory and the MMU (Memory Management Unit) is the hardware responsible for translating virtual addresses to physical addresses.

Entity-bootable_binary_disk_image.label: bootable binary disk image
Entity-bootable_binary_disk_image.description: A bootable binary disk image is a software artifact that contains a complete copy of a file system, including the operating system and necessary files, which can be used to boot a computer or virtual machine.

Entity-software_level.label: software level
Entity-software_level.description: The term 'software level' refers to the layer of security measures and protocols implemented within software systems to protect against vulnerabilities, such as those exposed by the Meltdown and Spectre incidents, highlighting the importance of addressing both software and hardware security.

Entity-halt_code.label: Halt Code
Entity-halt_code.description: Halt Code refers to a programming concept related to the instructions or code that terminates the execution of a program or process within the context of operating system development.

Entity-meltdown-spectre.label: Meltdown-Spectre
Entity-meltdown-spectre.description: Meltdown-Spectre refers to a class of security vulnerabilities that exploit speculative execution in modern processors, allowing unauthorized access to sensitive data.

Entity-mmu.label: MMU
Entity-mmu.description: MMU refers to the Memory Management Unit, a hardware component responsible for handling memory access and management tasks in computer systems, particularly in the context of paging in operating systems.

Entity-linux_distribution.label: Linux distributions
Entity-linux_distribution.description: Linux distributions are various versions of the Linux operating system that are packaged with different software and configurations to meet specific user needs.

Entity-emulation_device.label: emulation devices
Entity-emulation_device.description: Emulation devices are virtual hardware components used in system emulation environments, such as QEMU, that allow the execution of an operating system as if it were running on physical hardware.

Entity-bootstrap_process.label: bootstrap process
Entity-bootstrap_process.description: The bootstrap process refers to a sequence of steps or procedures used to initialize a system or software environment, often involving the loading and preparation of necessary components for operation.

Entity-c._bootloader.label: C. Bootloader
Entity-c._bootloader.description: C. Bootloader refers to a type of software that initializes hardware during the booting process and loads the operating system or other software components.

Entity-programming_language.label: programming languages
Entity-programming_language.description: Programming languages are formal languages comprising a set of instructions that can be used to produce various kinds of output, primarily used for writing software programs.

Entity-commercially_open_license.label: commercially open license
Entity-commercially_open_license.description: A commercially open license refers to a type of legal agreement that allows for the unrestricted use, modification, and distribution of software or hardware designs, promoting fairness and accessibility in the design and production processes.

Entity-porting.label: porting
Entity-porting.description: Porting refers to the process of adapting software so that it can operate in a different environment or platform than the one for which it was originally designed.

Entity-hardware_weakness.label: hardware weakness
Entity-hardware_weakness.description: Hardware weakness refers to vulnerabilities in computer hardware that can be exploited, such as the Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities, which arise from issues like speculative memory access.

Entity-the_meltdown_and_spectre_vulnerab.label: the Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities
Entity-the_meltdown_and_spectre_vulnerab.description: The Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities are critical security flaws in modern microprocessors that exploit speculative execution, allowing unauthorized access to sensitive data and highlighting the need for hardware-level security measures.

Entity-grub.label: GRUB
Entity-grub.description: GRUB is a widely used bootloader software that facilitates the loading of operating systems on computer systems.

Entity-memory_usage.label: memory usage
Entity-memory_usage.description: Memory usage refers to the amount of computer memory that is being utilized by processes or applications at a given time.

Entity-spectre.label: Spectre
Entity-spectre.description: Spectre refers to a security vulnerability that exploits speculative execution in modern processors, allowing unauthorized access to sensitive data.

Entity-command.label: commands
Entity-command.description: In the context of bootloaders, 'commands' refer to the specific instructions or options provided by the bootloader that allow users to debug or modify the operating system kernel environment prior to its booting.

Entity-paging.label: Paging
Entity-paging.description: Paging is a memory management scheme that eliminates the need for contiguous allocation of physical memory and enables the efficient use of memory by dividing it into fixed-size blocks called pages.

Entity-bsd_license.label: BSD license
Entity-bsd_license.description: The BSD license is a permissive open source software license that allows software to be freely used, modified, and distributed with minimal restrictions.

Entity-u-boot.label: U-boot
Entity-u-boot.description: U-boot is an open-source bootloader commonly used in embedded systems to initialize hardware and load operating systems.

Entity-pure_linux_usage_and_development_.label: pure Linux usage and development experience
aliases: pure Linux usage and development experience
Entity-pure_linux_usage_and_development_.description: The term 'pure Linux usage and development experience' refers to an open development environment that allows developers to engage with and utilize Linux in its most unaltered form, facilitating the creation and management of software without reliance on pre-existing distributions or modifications.

mentions.local_name: pure Linux usage and development experience

Entity-backward_compatibility.label: backward compatibility
Entity-backward_compatibility.description: Backward compatibility is a design feature of a system that allows it to work with inputs, interfaces, or data from previous versions of the system.

Entity-bap_unit.label: BAP unit
Entity-bap_unit.description: The BAP unit refers to a support unit at Akdeniz University that provides assistance for the MILIS Linux project, which is a Linux distribution initiative.

Entity-software.label: software
Entity-software.description: Software refers to a collection of programs, data, and instructions that enable computers and devices to perform specific tasks or functions.

Entity-developer.label: developers
Entity-developer.description: The term 'developers' refers to individuals or professionals engaged in the creation and enhancement of software, specifically within the context of the MILIS Linux project, which offers an open development platform for building and utilizing Linux-based systems.

Entity-testing.label: testing
Entity-testing.description: In the context of software development, 'testing' refers to the process of evaluating and verifying that a software application or system functions correctly and meets specified requirements, particularly when using physical hardware to achieve more accurate results.

Entity-processor_market.label: processor market
Entity-processor_market.description: The processor market refers to the economic sector that encompasses the production, distribution, and sale of computer processors and related semiconductor technologies.

Entity-yocto.label: Yocto
Entity-yocto.description: Yocto is a project and build system that enables the creation of custom Linux distributions and embedded Linux systems.

Entity-emulator.label: emulator
Entity-emulator.description: An emulator is a software or virtualization tool that enables one computer system to mimic the functions of another, allowing software designed for the emulated system to run on the host system.

Entity-bbl_elf_file.label: BBL ELF file
Entity-bbl_elf_file.description: The BBL ELF file is a binary file format used by the Berkeley Bootloader (BBL) that directly links the Linux kernel binary, enabling it to boot on RISC-V architecture.

Entity-computational_operation.label: computational operations
Entity-computational_operation.description: Computational operations refer to the fundamental processes or tasks performed by computers to manipulate data, which can include mathematical calculations, data processing, and algorithmic functions.

Entity-full_system_emulation_mode.label: full system emulation mode
Entity-full_system_emulation_mode.description: Full system emulation mode is a virtualization technique that simulates an entire computer system, allowing the execution of unmodified guest operating systems by emulating all hardware components.

Entity-2019.description: The mention '2019' refers to the year when the MILIS Linux project began receiving support from the Akdeniz University BAP unit.

Entity-user-facing_api.label: User-facing API
Entity-user-facing_api.description: A User-facing API is an application programming interface designed to be directly interacted with by end users, providing functionalities and services that facilitate user engagement with software applications.

Entity-default_boot_loading_process.label: default boot loading process
Entity-default_boot_loading_process.description: The default boot loading process is a sequence of operations that initializes a computer's operating system by loading the necessary software from storage into memory during the startup phase.

Entity-gcc_9.1.label: GCC 9.1
Entity-gcc_9.1.description: GCC 9.1 is a version of the GNU Compiler Collection, which is a set of programming language compilers used for software development.

Entity-infrastructure.label: Infrastructure
Entity-infrastructure.description: Infrastructure refers to the fundamental systems and structures that support the operation and functionality of a society or organization, including physical facilities, services, and frameworks necessary for economic activity and public welfare.

Entity-bootloaders.label: Bootloaders
Entity-bootloaders.description: Bootloaders are specialized software components that initialize the operating system during the booting process and provide options for loading the OS kernel and configuring the system environment.

Entity-qemu_4.0.0.label: QEMU 4.0.0
Entity-qemu_4.0.0.description: QEMU 4.0.0 is a specific version of the QEMU software, which is an open-source emulator and virtualizer that allows users to run multiple operating systems on a single host machine.

Entity-gnu.label: GNU
Entity-gnu.description: GNU is a free software operating system and project that promotes the development of free software and provides a collection of tools and utilities for software development.

Entity-private_user.label: private users
Entity-private_user.description: Private users refer to individual consumers or non-commercial entities that utilize the MILIS Linux operating system for personal or private computing needs.

Entity-boot_chain_loading.label: Boot chain loading
Entity-boot_chain_loading.description: Boot chain loading is a method in the boot process where one bootloader loads another bootloader, facilitating the initialization of an operating system.

Entity-elf.label: ELF
Entity-elf.description: ELF refers to the Executable and Linkable Format, a common file format for executable files, object code, shared libraries, and core dumps used in Unix and Unix-like operating systems.

Entity-compilation_tool.label: compilation tools
Entity-compilation_tool.description: Compilation tools are software applications or utilities that automate the process of converting source code written in a programming language into executable code or machine code.

Entity-config_parameter.label: config parameter
Entity-config_parameter.description: A config parameter is a variable or setting that determines the behavior or configuration of a software application or system.

Entity-development_life-cycle.label: development life-cycle
Entity-development_life-cycle.description: The development life-cycle refers to the structured process or methodology that outlines the stages and activities involved in the creation, development, and maintenance of a product or system.

Entity-accurate.label: accurate
Entity-accurate.description: The term 'accurate' in this context refers to the precision and reliability of results obtained from compilation and testing processes when conducted on actual physical hardware, as opposed to simulations.

Entity-distro_developer.label: distro developers
Entity-distro_developer.description: Distro developers are professionals who create, maintain, and enhance Linux distributions, focusing on software packaging, system configuration, and user experience.

Entity-timer_interrupt.label: timer interrupts
Entity-timer_interrupt.description: Timer interrupts are signals generated by a timer to indicate that a specified time period has elapsed, prompting the operating system to execute a specific task or routine.

Entity-debugging.label: debugging
Entity-debugging.description: Debugging is the process of identifying, analyzing, and resolving errors or bugs in software or hardware systems to ensure proper functionality.

Entity-linux_community.label: Linux community
Entity-linux_community.description: The Linux community is a global collective of developers, users, and enthusiasts who collaborate on the development and promotion of the Linux operating system and its associated software.

Entity-qemu_s_full_system_emulation_mode.label: QEMU's full system emulation mode
Entity-qemu_s_full_system_emulation_mode.description: QEMU's full system emulation mode is a feature of the QEMU emulator that allows for the emulation of an entire hardware system, enabling the execution of unmodified guest operating systems as if they were running on actual hardware.

Entity-industry_4.0.label: Industry 4.0
Entity-industry_4.0.description: Industry 4.0 refers to the fourth industrial revolution characterized by the integration of advanced technologies such as the Internet of Things (IoT), artificial intelligence, and automation into manufacturing and industrial processes.

Entity-package_manager.label: package manager
Entity-package_manager.description: A package manager is a software tool that automates the process of installing, upgrading, configuring, and removing software packages, as well as managing their dependencies.

Entity-2014.description: The mention '2014' refers to the year when Debian produced a port related to open source hardware studies.

Entity-binary_disk_image.label: binary disk image
Entity-binary_disk_image.description: A binary disk image is a file that contains a complete copy of the data and structure of a disk, including the operating system, applications, and files, typically used for storage, backup, or distribution purposes.

Entity-f._bootable_image.label: F. Bootable Image
Entity-f._bootable_image.description: F. Bootable Image refers to a type of file or system image that contains the necessary data to boot an operating system or software application directly from a storage medium.

Entity-kernel_environment.label: kernel environment
Entity-kernel_environment.description: The 'kernel environment' refers to the configuration and settings that can be modified by bootloaders to prepare and manage the operating system kernel before it is executed.

Entity-more_accurate_result.label: more accurate results
Entity-more_accurate_result.description: The term 'more accurate results' refers to the improved precision and reliability of outcomes obtained from compilation and testing processes when conducted on actual physical hardware, as opposed to simulations or virtual environments.

Entity-workflow.label: workflow
Entity-workflow.description: A workflow is a structured sequence of processes or methodologies designed to accomplish a specific task or set of tasks efficiently.

Entity-community_driven_design.label: community driven design
Entity-community_driven_design.description: Community driven design is a collaborative approach to design that emphasizes the involvement and input of a community in the development process, often leveraging open-source principles to create solutions that meet the needs of its users.

Entity-mission_critical_project.label: mission critical projects
Entity-mission_critical_project.description: Mission critical projects are initiatives or tasks that are essential for the success and operation of an organization, where failure to execute them can result in significant negative consequences.

Entity-internet_of_thing.label: Internet of Things
Entity-internet_of_thing.description: The Internet of Things (IoT) refers to the network of interconnected devices and objects that communicate and exchange data over the internet, enabling automation and smart functionalities.

Entity-binutils.label: Binutils
Entity-binutils.description: Binutils is a collection of binary tools used for the manipulation of binary files, including object files, archives, and executables, commonly utilized in software development and toolchains.

Entity-elf_file.label: ELF file
Entity-elf_file.description: An ELF file is a common file format for executable files, object code, shared libraries, and core dumps, primarily used in Unix and Unix-like operating systems.

Entity-optimization.label: optimization
Entity-optimization.description: Optimization is a systematic process or technique aimed at making something as effective, efficient, or functional as possible.

Entity-this_time.label: this time
Entity-this_time.description: In this context, 'this time' refers to the current moment or period in which the feasibility of 128-bit operation is being evaluated, indicating that such an operation is not considered practical or achievable at the present moment.

Entity-command_for_debugging_andor_modif.label: commands for debugging and/or modifying the kernel environment
aliases: commands for debugging and/or modifying the kernel environment
Entity-command_for_debugging_andor_modif.description: Commands for debugging and/or modifying the kernel environment refer to the instructions embedded within bootloaders that allow users to interact with and alter the operating system's kernel settings and behavior prior to the boot process.

Entity-storage_device.label: storage devices
Entity-storage_device.description: Storage devices are hardware components used to store digital data, including various types such as hard drives, solid-state drives, and flash memory.

Entity-web_browser.label: web browser
Entity-web_browser.description: A web browser is a software application used to access and navigate the internet, allowing users to view and interact with web pages.

Entity-binutils_2.32.label: Binutils 2.32
Entity-binutils_2.32.description: Binutils 2.32 is a version of a collection of binary tools used for the manipulation of binary files, including object files, archives, and executables, commonly utilized in software development and toolchain environments.

Entity-r__d_study.label: R&D studies
Entity-r__d_study.description: R&D studies refer to systematic investigations and experiments conducted by organizations to develop new products, technologies, or processes, often involving both research and development activities.

Entity-iit_madras.label: IIT Madras

summary:
Abstract—As is commonly known, hardware in a computer system requires a processor to run the operating system. The primary architectures that form the basis of most processors are CISC and RISC. CISC includes long sub-level commands for effective memory management and simple compiler implementations to be developed. Thus CISC has a complex set of commands; hence the name Complex Instruction Set Computer. On the other hand, CISC has had backward compatibility since the 1970s. Reduced Instruction Set Computer (RISC), the other popular architecture, simplifies command sets and handles access to memory with load-store commands. Since the instruction set is simplified, the hardware runs faster. In addition, RISC-based processors contain less chip-sets and may be designed faster. Currently, with the prevalence of the Internet of Things (IoT), the demand for RISC architectures has increased and its usage in embedded devices has become widespread. The ARM processor is a successful example of the RISC architecture adaptation. However, ARM processor production has certain license term limitations and contains a few design flaws in its architecture [1]. In 2010, the RISC-V processor architecture, which was developed as an open source instruction set at Berkeley University, paves the way for open source hardware in terms of its BSD license and design professionalism. As a result, it will be possible to produce their own processors for communities and organizations without license restrictions. In this paper, we discuss the building blocks of the development life-cycle of an open source operating system on the RISC-V architecture. As an operating system base, we implement MILIS Linux, an open source operating system development project. It has an independent user space and its own package manager. For a completely independent open source computing system, open source RISC-V hardware architecture provides the freedom that is needed.

RISC-V is an open-source instruction set architecture (ISA) that offers a more homogeneous set of instructions compared to CISC, optimizing execution and minimizing memory usage. It addresses vulnerabilities like Meltdown and Spectre by promoting hardware-level security and open-source collaboration. The RISC-V foundation includes contributions from various global institutions, and its architecture supports a wide range of applications. MILIS Linux, initiated in 2016, is an independent Linux distribution aimed at providing a user-friendly operating system, particularly for government and commercial use. It is not based on existing distributions and aims to create an open-source ecosystem. The MILIS project is now developing a fork to support RISC-V architecture, targeting embedded devices and IoT applications, with the goal of being among the first open-source Linux OS for RISC-V.

SiFive has developed several motherboards for RISC-V processors, leading to increased support for Linux distributions. Legacy distributions like Debian are porting to RISC-V, while Fedora is creating a native OS and tracking compilation online. Buildroot has also been adapted for 64-bit RISC-V, supporting both native and original implementations. This paper focuses on enhancing kernel support and reducing porting times through a reference implementation based on MILIS, aiming to build a Linux from Scratch and improve user-space applications.

MILIS Linux is successfully running on 64-bit systems, focusing on RISC-V architecture. The project aims to create kernel and userspace packages for a 64-bit little-endian RISC-V system, with future considerations for 32-bit and 128-bit configurations. Key components include: A. System Emulation using QEMU for development without hardware; B. Toolchain with GCC 9.1 and Binutils 2.32, utilizing Glibc 2.29 for RISC-V support; C. Bootloader options like Berkley Bootloader (BBL) for kernel execution, which requires rebuilding with the kernel; D. Ongoing work on the Linux kernel and userspace, including init code, device handling, and user APIs; E. Pre-Root File System creation through cross-compilation for a bootable OS; F. Bootable Image production from MILIS packages for distribution. The RISC-V Linux port is included in the Linux tree since 2017, marking significant progress.

This paper discusses the RISC-V processor, highlighting its open-source, community-driven design and potential for mission-critical applications, especially in the Internet of Things. With many companies investing in R&D for RISC-V and joining the RISC-V foundation, its market popularity is expected to rise. The paper emphasizes the need for a reliable open-source operating system, proposing Linux as the ideal kernel. While port migration of Linux distributions is underway, the focus is on developing a robust user ecosystem on the Linux kernel through the MILIS Linux project. This initiative aims to enhance IT processes and will benefit from the open computing proposal.

A. Physical Implementation and Optimizations The work outline performed on the QEMU virtual machine discussed in this study will be applied on a real board based on RISC-V processor. Compilation and testing will give more accurate results using physical hardware. Thus, we will have a better understanding of the components that will need to be optimized. The compilation tools that we use in the bootstrap process will offer more RISC-V support over time and will be optimized. In addition, alternative libraries instead of Glibc, which we currently use as C libraries, will be evaluated. Also, with the RISC-V support in the LLVM Compiler Infrastructure [31], native compile support will be increased at the level of programming languages which use LLVM as back-end compiler. RISC-V porting will be further explored for the kernel level difficulties encountered while providing the necessary solutions. The necessary sponsors and research project funding supports will be provided for the R&D studies and RISC-V processors with different features will be obtained and the studies will be performed on real equipment.

B. The Future: Open Hardware and Open Source Operating System Open hardware means license-free; namely with RISC-V virtually anyone can produce potentially better evaluations and much more accurate comparisons with existing works. There is a range of high quality, open-source RISC-V implementations to modify, rather than just based on estimating or simulations. Also opening standard will bring about a more active development community so that when sharing patches or ideas, projects will get contributions more quickly. As of now one aspect of the RISC-V Foundation is responding to proposals and discussing them. The other aspect is producing proposed changes either in a future specification revision or in hardware. On the other hand, opening the standards and having a commercially open license would certainly make the processor design and production race more fair. Also RISC-V will bring a new synergy of open source computer architecture research areas, such as universities started to establish research groups on RISC-V, such as OpenCelerity [32] and SCARV [33]. Research is expected to be carried out on real hardware with the increase of RISC-V processor manufacturers. As a result, Linux kernel and userspace seems the best candidate software stack for RISC-V.

Predicate-requires.label: requires
